name: 4-propylphenol
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.
Reason: The base unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The hydroxyl (OH) group generally increases the melting point due to the ability to form hydrogen bonds, which can be estimated to raise the melting point by 80 degrees Celsius. The propyl group adds hydrophobic bulk, which slightly reduces the melting point as it can disrupt the crystal lattice, estimated to lower the melting point by -10 degrees Celsius. Combined, these groups influence the melting point in opposite directions, but the strong hydrogen bonding capability of the hydroxyl group has a major raising effect.

The combined effects of OH raising and the propyl group lowering the melting point must be considered to predict the accurate melting point.

name: 4-propylphenol
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.
Reason: Target compound: 4-propylphenol. For similar aromatic compounds, the basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 °C. Phenol, which has a hydroxyl group attached to benzene, has a melting point of 41 °C. This indicates that the hydroxyl group raises the melting point by approximately 35.5 °C due to hydrogen bonding capabilities. The propyl group is an alkyl chain, which tends to lower the melting point as it disrupts the planarity and packing efficiency in the crystal lattice. A propyl group on benzene (propylbenzene) is estimated to lower the melting point by around 20 °C when compared to benzene, due to its ability to disrupt the crystal packing and increase the molecular volume resultant in a less efficient lattice packing. In the prediction, the addition of the hydroxyl group and the propyl group effects are combined with the baseline of benzene.
